title: Thursday, 15th February, 2018
bodyHTML:
wayneJ Morning
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Okay, let's get on. Markets Live. FT Alphaville's daily etc.

Blank canvas good morning all
Markkus morning all
BE11:05am

Guess we start with this chap.

BE11:05am

OnYourRight Morning all....... Does anyone have any thoughts on US CPI ex Autos and Energy?
Miss Piggy UST 10 year 2.93 now higer than Aussie
Soundbuy Hello.....
Mouselet Good morning
Miss Piggy Cyril?
11:06 am
BE11:06am

The one on the left is Cyril Ramaphosa, of course. Trade unionist to multi millionaire to South African president. Ushering a new era of .... well, who knows?

rwl Hello.
BE11:07am

Joseph's updates are definitive here: https://www.ft.com...-8cb6-b9ccc4c4dbbb

OnYourRight A new era of "the same"
Grouchmonkey Morning
BE11:07am

And the market, as the market tends to, is reading change from X to Y as an improvement.

Bonnemort SA lady MP this morning really chalked Humphrys off "You're putting words in my mouth. A journalist should ask me questions and let me reply"
11:07 am
Old Mutual PLC (OML:LSE): Last: 249.40, up 10 (+4.18%), High: 251.70, Low: 244.10, Volume: 6.80m
Miss Piggy ZAR wars
Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 393.40, up 11 (+2.88%), High: 394.95, Low: 387.30, Volume: 13.36m
Lonmin PLC (LMI:LSE): Last: 74.30, up 2.15 (+2.98%), High: 75.25, Low: 72.30, Volume: 220.42k
11:08 am
Mondi PLC (MNDI:LSE): Last: 1,856, up 64 (+3.57%), High: 1,859, Low: 1,809, Volume: 440.91k
rwl Nice one Cyril!
Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 1,738, up 44.2 (+2.61%), High: 1,756, Low: 1,734, Volume: 1.73m
A. M. @ Bonnemort -- what words were these?
BE11:09am

Rand's somewhere near a three-year high, bond yields distinctly firmer.

Bonnemort He was doing the usual interview - two paragraphs of Humphrys to one sentence from interviewee.
11:09 am
BE11:09am

And .... well, here's a weird quirk!

estrangedcapitalist Morning from Venice gents
Peace and Love re SA: Plus ca change moins ca change
wayneJ Someone forgot to give the memo to S32
BE11:10am

The ANC has stated it will nominate Mr Ramaphosa, who could lead the country for as many as 11 years, from now until the national election in 2029.

BE11:10am

Huh?

Miss Piggy @estrangedcapitalist are you in an Italian toilet then?
11:10 am
BE11:10am

South Africa has a two term limit for the president, but when a person is elected to fill a presidential vacancy, the period until the next national poll is not regarded as a term.

estrangedcapitalist Romantic few days with the misses here. Out-negotiated a gondola operator
BE11:10am

Ah.

BE11:10am

That's ..... not ideal?

pfd NG making new lows.
rwl US CPI - what happened yesterday- quick turnaround of equity indices ?
Badger The misses? What happened to the missus?
11:11 am
BE11:11am

Anyway, here's HSBC to say the leadership transition should reduce political uncertainty, while also creating the potential for changes to the cabinet and government policy.

Bonnemort On Valentine's day in Venice? Impressive
BE11:11am

The leadership transition should reduce political uncertainty, while also creating the potential for changes to the cabinet and government policy. The timing of cabinet changes, and how far-reaching they could be, remains uncertain, with internal party dynamics likely to influence these moves. However, given the relative ease of political change so far, we believe there is a good chance that the cabinet could be overhauled relatively quickly.

estrangedcapitalist @ Miss Piggy - we get it, you missed btc. I did not.
Bonnemort (the out-negotiation)
BE11:12am

If cabinet and policy adjustments are possible, there could also be some quick changes which could foster better sentiment, including Mr Ramaphosa following through with his anti-corruption stance, and decisions that start to tackle uncertainty in contentious policy areas such as the mining charter, energy policy and the role of nuclear power in the energy mix, and governance concerns about the country's state-owned enterprises.

red @rwlopening gap to upside today by 50dma. v key level on close. if we go up first i suspect we finish down. if we fill gap to downside first but hold gap can go up. but 50dma is a great place for those bearish to sell some more stocks.
Pinsticker Estranged - know a very nice restaurant in Venice - seafood platter very reasonable
estrangedcapitalist @ Pinsticker please let me know
11:12 am
BE11:12am

We are cautious on near-term growth prospects (forecasting GDP growth of 1.2% in 2018 and 2019), but recognise that progress in these policy areas could support stronger cyclical gains if they enable a recovery in confidence and underpin further ZAR strength that lowers inflation, potentially opening the space for interest rate cuts and a more robust growth improvement as private investment and household consumption rebounds

rwl @redThnks! wil keep watching !
BE11:13am

We get an SA budget on the 21st, by the way, and between now and then Cyril has to terminate all of Zuma's cabinet.

Shinshin @BE - isn't that the same in US though ? (effective three term thing)
BE11:14am

SocGen incoming.

Blank canvas Has Mondi announced its special dividend, or is the 4% jump just following the sector?
Soundbuy 'terminate'.........hmmmmm
A. M. Can he purge the gov't?
11:15 am
BE11:15am

Ramaphosa still faces an uphill climb. The country’s new leader will face the manyfold challenges of:
o Reuniting a deeply factional ANC, in preparation for the country’s general elections in spring 2019
o Reviving South Africa’s anaemic GDP growth
o Stabilizing public debt ratios and restoring fiscal sustainability
o Restoring confidence in the independence of state institutions (including the National Prosecuting Authority and the South African Revenue Services)
o Addressing corporate governance and financial issues at state-owned enterprises (SOEs)
o Weeding out instances of corruption and state capture in government
o Delivering on the resolutions adopted by the ANC at the December conference without compromising market sentiment and investor confidence

estrangedcapitalist @ Bonnemort - negotiation is key. tried to pull a quick one. 20 min but promised 40 min. wasn't having it. went off with some expletives in Italian and nearly pushed him in the canal
A. M. (from a practical standpoint)
rwl Anyone follows SLA? down 5% - apparent reason: contract cancellation by LLOY
Rick Chasey Can I just say, Tom Hale on millennial savings: bang on.
BE11:16am

Anyway. market's very underweight SA and the Moody's reprieve plus the rand strength is enough to push some cash in. Not sure there's more to say really.

rwl SA - long to do list for the new chap!
red @rwlits a good reason for markdown. but with no loose ends.
BE11:17am

Nevertheless, have RBC on Anglo.

11:17 am
Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 1,744, up 50.4 (+2.98%), High: 1,756, Low: 1,734, Volume: 1.78m
Soundbuy @Blank C - Mondi SA inspiried move I'd guess.......
nichoman @rwl well yes, could be a few hundred million quid lost in management fees
BE11:18am

In regards to earnings, with South Africa accounting for 22% of the NAV, but at least in part contributing to the now narrowed 15% discount to our global diversified sector average multiple (4.6x vs. 5.2x), the impact on EBITDA only a minor negative - we calculate a 2% difference from our 2018 forecast (ZAR12.75) vs. spot of ~ZAR11.75. Longer-term however, this currency impact will have a larger difference should this be sustained. We highlight the rand has a 5yr R-squared of 84% to the Bloomberg Commodity Index, so it's likely incorrect to attribute too much long-term impact from this change.

From a sentiment perspective however, this should vastly increase interest in Anglo American, a company which is on the RBC Global Top 30 ideas for 2018. The emergence of a more pro-business ANC should allow for an improved operating environment. There is also a greater likelihood that Anglo, should it desire to, could make structural changes to its corporate structure that could streamline previous challenges like the capital controls on South African profits, etc. Short-term however there may be an element that as above this has been, in the main, priced in.

Mouselet Rick Chasey: indeed! Inter-generational wealth transfer dwarfs the possibilities of saving
undefined
Mouselet Basically we want a wealthy-uncle state rather than a nanny state
11:19 am
BE11:19am

And so to the absurdly named Standard Life Aberdeen?

Standard Life Aberdeen PLC (SLA:LSE): Last: 369.60, down 19.7 (-5.06%), High: 377.00, Low: 351.00, Volume: 9.83m
BE11:19am

Came down quick but has now leveled off a bit.

Miss Piggy https://ftalphaville.ft.com/2018/02/15/2198809/someone-is-wrong-on-the-internet-millennial-savings-edition/
Shinshin Just popped over to USian colleague for quick Civics primer. US can be ten years, if VP takes over more than 50% way through can stand for two more giving max ten. If takes over less than 50% through can only stand once.
Pharma @Mouselet, ideally a *dead* wealthy uncle.
rwl @red, nichoman - Re SL - somewhat surprised Scottish Widows (part f LLOY) ditching their old friend/rival so suddenly
11:20 am
BE11:20am

Following news that Scottish Widows is pulling £109bn of assets under management, resulting in a £40m exceptional.

Grouchmonkey So who gets Lloyds' business now?
BE11:21am

Couple of things to note here. First, the margin on the Scottish Widows funds looks garbage! As in, 13 basis points garbage.

Mouselet pharma: I prefer the generous but living kind, they tend to have nice houses to stay in
red @rwlu only help youre rival out while it helps u. otherwise whats the point
Bonnemort @estrangescapitalist - well done. I've negotiated down in advance, but not on Valentine's!,
BE11:22am

Group level, Standard Life has a rake of about 33 basis points. "Growth" does 50 plus.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

So, losing legacy management contracts isn't the disaster it first looks.

BE11:23am

More important, arguably, is what it says about Lloyds.

BE11:23am

The six-month lock on funds post the Standard-Aberdeen merger expired literally yesterday. They've wasted no time here.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

And it's ahead of a strategic rethink at Lloyds to reflect its change from state-owned basket case to thrusting loans engine of an emboldened UK. You won't need reminded that these kind of strategic rethinks don't always go swimmingly.

Pharma @Mouselet, I was only dreaming. None of my uncles are/were wealthy (nor indeed are any other relatives. Most inconsiderate of them).
BE11:26am

Goodbody's banks team is excellent on this theme.

Mouselet I _am_ the wealthy uncle in my bit of the family :(
BE11:26am

LLOY’s will present its FY17 results and strategic update next Wednesday, 21st February. Our latest sector research report contained a piece on LLOY’s forthcoming strategic update in which we noted that we expect to see something radical – and that a substantive investment in technology (potentially involving a partnership with the likes of a Temenos just like BIRG and NDA have done) is potentially on the horizon. While the long-term benefits of such investments are very real, the market typically does not react fondly to news of such investments in the short-run due to the drain on capital. We expressed our view in that piece that LLOY shareholders should consider taking some money off the table ahead of the Strategic Update – and our view has not changed.

rwl @redI know who I trust better to look after my funds! BE makes a good point !
11:26 am
Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 67.54, up 0.89 (+1.34%), High: 67.82, Low: 66.86, Volume: 39.88m
BE11:27am

However, back to STAberdeen

wayneJ @BE - how does that maths work? Consensus operating profit for 2018 is £1.149bn - 13bps on £109bn is £141MThis should all be high incremental margin business so could potentially be a > 10% hit on operating profit or is my maths wrong?
BE11:28am

The AUM hit isn't great but, largely, we're now just talking about how quickly costs can come out to match the new shape of the business.

wayneJ Surely the point about a fund manager is that incremental AUM is at very high incremental margin on the way up - can be close to 80% or more incremental operating margin.
11:29 am
BE11:29am

Here's Numis, in particular for @WayneJ who has made the mistake of asking me about maths.

BE11:30am

We estimate the financial impact on the group would be smaller than the c.15% share of AuM: we estimate the c.5% revenue loss will translate to a c.8% loss of profits and c.5% of value. This is because Lloyds pays an estimated c.14bps fee margin (vs. SLA average c.34bps) and in our view the attributable earnings are worth a lower multiple than the group (SWIP was bought by Aberdeen in a competitive bid process for a c.8x P/E multiple and given the run-off nature of 50%+ of the AuM). In summary, we believe the direct financial impact will be less material than one might think given the scale of the asset loss.

wayneJ And on the way down management typically cuts the experienced older fund managers as they are usually the most costly - and then finds that teenage analysts have never been through a downturn and have no gravitas with clients so more AUM leaves the building....
BE11:30am

We estimate Lloyds contributes c.£140m of the group's c.£2.8bn
revenues, i.e. c.5%. Attributing the reported 60% marginal operating margin reportedly achieved by Aberdeen on SWIP post-merger, this implies a c.£84m contribution to group PBT of c.£1.1bn, i.e. c.8%. Taxing at 19% and putting on an 8x multiple, suggests £544m of value to the group, equivalent to c.5% of the current market cap

11:30 am
BE11:31am

....... which is exactly how much they're down, conveniently.

undefined
wayneJ Looks to me that Numis are also making the same mistake that every product has the same group operating margin....
BE11:32am

What else do we have?

11:32 am
BE11:33am

There's another bloody Melrose statement in response to another bloody GKN statement that was in response to another bloody Melrose statement that was in response to another bloody GKN statement.

GKN PLC (GKN:LSE): Last: 418.30, up 7 (+1.70%), High: 419.40, Low: 408.70, Volume: 2.71m
Melrose Industries PLC (MRO:LSE): Last: 228.80, up 7.7 (+3.48%), High: 228.90, Low: 222.50, Volume: 3.95m
#REF! belated hello all
#REF! GKN and Melrose should have one rap/diss battle and then shut up. Get it all out of the way. Tedious now
11:34 am
BE11:34am

I won't try to summarise the details, because the phrase "tit for tat" has already been invented and that suffices.

SB from VB Indivior down 12%?
BE11:35am

What we can note is Melrose share price strength over the past couple of day, which seems to suggest investors believe it has a greater likelihood of landing this one.

wayneJ So please help me ---- Reuters and Bloomberg are both saying it is £109bn - Numis in the Grey says it is at 14bps - surely that is £152M of rv and at 60% op margin (which is too low) that is £91.56M of op profit? (not the £84M in the grey) - anyone check my maths?
BE11:36am

There's a very long Barclays note putting a 538p target on GKN, as in 30% or so above Melrose's offer.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Sorry -- that's the SOTP not the target. The target continues to build in the possibility of failure.

BE11:37am

When the MRO offer was announced GKN shareholders were unclear on the value in the business they owned but clear that the existing strategy was not delivering returns. Since then the company has highlighted the hidden value in parts of the business such as e-Drive and Aero Engines, which was unclear due to poor disclosure. Yesterday new management presented a strategy that, whilst simple, strikes us as the right approach to follow to improve financial returns. We increase our PT to 470p.

wayneJ Also by losing AUM does that increase the exposure of SLA to pensions and insurance etc - should that have a higher risk premium than a straightforward asset manager? I invite anyone to decipher the balance sheet of SLA....
rwl OT- For those who follow Russian politics and the Trump connection - this video might be of interest - it is in Russian but already has had close to 5m hits https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RQZr2NgKPiU
BE11:39am

The new strategy to grow areas achieving decent returns, focus on
improving returns not growth in areas achieving substandard returns, and continue to invest in new technologies could be straight out of an MBA book, but that doesn’t mean it’s wrong. Management was also clear that past incentives were too muddled and clearer incentives were important to drive the transformation. Unfortunately little information was provided on what these incentives might look like other than that they could result in a £70m payout. Wenote the strategy only targets a ≥10.5% margin for the total group, slightly ahead of the prior 8-10% targeted range with an additional 0.5% from margin-accretive disposals, but we think management has given itself 100bps of headroom to achieve this. We estimate 2021 FCF under management’s plan to be 43% higher than our prior forecasts (66% higher including an additional 6% from lower tax and 17% from higher Aero engine FCF).

11:40 am
BE11:40am

And as to the Melrose angle .....

BE11:40am

rom an overall perspective we believe the central question remains unchanged – ‘which management team do you back?’ – albeit based on the structure of the deal as it currently stands GKN’s management do not have to deliver quite the same level of benefit as Melrose to deliver the same return to existing GKN shareholders (81p in cash and 1.49 ‘New’ Melrose shares for each GKN share or c. 57% of ‘New’ Melrose or if GKN shareholders simply reinvested the 81pps of cash they would receive under the current terms of the offer in Melrose shares, then they could own c. 70% of ‘New Melrose’ based on the current share price and this, over and above progress at GKN, enables them to gain additional exposure to further progress at Nortek and longer term, potential further value creating deals Melrose may do). Anne Stevens, CEO of GKN, declared at yesterday’s presentation, with regard to the implementation of the proposed changes, that “this is not rocket science” and by the same token, from our perspective we see nothing that dims our view that GKN appears to be another suitable target for Melrose and ripe for improvement. Despite significant change in GKN’s central management (greater than 50% since October 2017), this team is unproven relative to the well known and proven track record of Melrose’s management.

Oshi Yamamoto hello
undefined
11:41 am
BE11:41am

Okay, so Indivior mentioned.

BE11:41am

(Though the comment might have been caught by the spam filter. Apologies. It's rather overactive sometimes.)

Indivior PLC (INDV:LSE): Last: 348.50, down 56.4 (-13.93%), High: 415.00, Low: 343.90, Volume: 1.69m
11:41 am
BE11:42am

Lots and lots of moving parts to the results ......

wayneJ So on a consensus estimate of £1.109BN of PBT (the number Numis is using) that is 8.25% - but that is assuming that the company is able to reduce expenses exactly in line with rv loss which is nuts...
BE11:42am

... with the 2018 guidance the most important bit, but also the most difficult to comprehend.

Lefevre @BE, Galliford bounced 5%, anything interesting been written 24 hours on?
BE11:43am

Because Indivior sets its 2018 guidance based on Suboxone generics not coming to market. Some analysts also base their forecasts on that, but not all.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Which makes the consensus nonsense.

BE11:44am

So, you'll see a lot of references around this morning about Indivior's guidance being 20% better than consensus. It's literally meaningless. The underlying picture, which takes some work to see, is what matters.

wayneJ And on the grey - if Numis thinks the hit is 8% of PBT why should it be only 5% of mkt cap - the analyst has in essence then used an arbitrary PE and tax rate to reduce the mkt cap impact.
BE11:44am

And the upshot there is that there's a Trump tax cut that disappears entirely by the bottom line. Suggesting S&GM costs are going to eat it.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

We also get another exceptional for legal costs, which is a pretty big indicator that Indivior expects to be on the hook for a fine.

BE11:46am

Post a very decent run for the stock, all this is being taken very badly.

BE11:46am

Here's RBC.

Oshi Yamamoto Trump tax cut just a quick sales thing what about the expansion of PD
11:46 am
BE11:47am

Indivior increased its provision for antitrust litigation matters to $438m (from $220m), which will likely weaken sentiment towards the shares (which are off 8.6% at the time of writing). We can only justify this share price reaction if the fine becomes greater in value (again), given the company has ample cash resources to pay this size fine. Elsewhere, there is no update on generic litigation, with this overhang likely to remain. The Subclocade launch is expected Feb 26 (on time) and we are positive on the launch prospects for this product given our recent survey work (link). Management are guiding to a modest amount of revenue in FY18E - we have $50m and we think there is scope for outperformance here.

BE11:47am

Overall, whilst the DoJ risk is likely to remain heavy on investor
sentiment we see today's share price weakness as an opportunity given the long-term potential for Indivior in what is a growth market.

BE11:48am

And Morgan Stanley, which is house broker.

Grouchmonkey To go back to my earlier Q on Lloyds/SLA, are Lloyds planning to take management back in house or to award the mandate to s.o. else, and if so, who are the likely candidates? Anyone know?
11:49 am
BE11:49am

The inclusion of another provision related to the investigations will lend credence to the idea that Indivior will need to pay a fine. While this is unrelated to underlying performance, this is impactful from a cash flow perspective (both in 3Q16 and now).

BE11:50am

On 2018 guidance, we would expect the focus to remain on topline, specifically on the decreasing market share and the mix as seen in this quarter, while on costs, SD&A costs will be in focus. We are not particularly surprised by higher SD&A costs as
they invest behind Sublocade, but this could hamper earnings growth. While we believe the company guiding to limited sales of Sublocade in 2018 is reasonable (and arguably conservative), we believe not disclosing sales of the product will limit investor visibility. We see no major update from either litigation or R&D. Overall, we see positives (above consensus guidance) and negatives (provision, SD&A investment and a weaker quarter), but especially given recent strength (in light of market downturn), we would be more cautious than not today.

Forester @grouchmonkey frankly at that margin I would sell the stock of anyone to won that contract!
BE11:51am

(@Grouchmonkey: I imagine they'll tell us at the strategic review, as we said earlier.)

11:50 am
undefined
nichoman Going back to GKN, has there been talk of any other bidders...been v quiet on that front
BE11:52am

Okay, so what have we not covered?

rwl any grey on AZN?
Finlay ALY ?
BE11:54am

(@Nichoman: haven't heard a thing about a counter. The problem with GKN was always, of course, that one side of the business acted as a poison pill for anyone wanting the other side. That remains true, I'd assume, and now management's in fighty mode it's going to take a very belligerent type to want to get involved.)

11:54 am
BE11:55am

Oh, this looks a great bit of work from Matt Campbell at Bloomberg: https://www.bloomb...a-piece-of-america

SB from VB Thanks !
Oshi Yamamoto God bless china
BE11:56am

Matt was a right pain when he ran the M&A team, because he was exceptionally good at it.

BE11:56am

Seems he's also exceptionally good at the long-read stuff as well.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

.... Anyway! Where were we?

BE11:57am

(@Finlay: please don't talk in tickers. I'm chucking out a few thousand words an hour over here, You can spare the time to type an entire company name.)

Finlay Sorry, Laura Ashley
Waterloo Does the VIX still work? Clear high volatility is back yet VIX at a low?
BE11:57am

AstraZeneca's just ex div, isn't it?

11:57 am
AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 4,728, down 102.5 (-2.12%), High: 4,743, Low: 4,703, Volume: 438.50k
BE11:58am

133.6p div, so flattish to up on the day.

rwl @BE- thanks re AstraZeneca
BE11:58am

Sellside wise there's a big UBS thing on Cineworld.

nichoman @BE thanks!
11:58 am
Cineworld Group PLC (CINE:LSE): Last: 240.20, up 3.2 (+1.35%), High: 243.80, Low: 238.40, Volume: 3.33m
BE11:59am

Saying the worries about the US are overcooked.

BE11:59am

We have assessed the structural debates in the US market, and conclude that whilst
there is structural pressure on admissions, we don’t expect to see structural decline in
box office revenues. In particular; (1) analysis of the weak 2017 US box office suggests
that 2017 should be treated as an anomaly not as evidence of accelerating structural
decline trend; (2) Assessing the threat of Netflix using the UBS Evidence Lab Spend
Tracker finds no evidence that Netflix usage is correlated with lower or faster declining
cinema attendance; and (3) We believe an opportunity remains to increase ticket prices
in the US given lower recent ATP growth in the US relative to UK.

PeterC RELX been one way...? Bond proxy?
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

So, having been sellers into the 30% drop from 2017 highs, they're now buyers.

BE12:00pm

Our cautious stance on Cineworld
up till now has been driven by concern around supply growth in the mature UK market,
which we didn’t see as reflected in the Cineworld rating. However, with the group now
trading on 7.6x 19E EV/EBITDA, and our reverse DCF indicating the market is pricing in
US box office revenues declining -0.5% p.a. vs. our UBSe +1%, along with our analysis
of the US market dynamics which gives us comfort that the market can continue to see
growth, we see the risk reward balance as attractive, and upgrade to Buy.

Blank canvas Thanks for everything today - left and right sides of the page
BE12:00pm

Management's track record following the successful combination of Cineworld and
Cinema City gives us confidence that the group will achieve their $100m synergy
target, supporting our forecast US EBITDA rising by 33% from 2017E-19E. In addition,
we believe that being the 2nd largest global cinema exhibitor will strengthen the
group's position with the studios, in particular in the context of ongoing discussions
around PVOD, which we don’t expect to be resolved in the short term.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

PVOD?

BE12:01pm

First ten hits on Google are for https://en.wikiped...oocclusive_disease

Grouchmonkey ..something Video on Demand?
Oshi Yamamoto its a blockage bryce
Plato the Cook Pay View On Demand?
Otter POVD = Popcorn & Vimto On Demand
Grouchmonkey V good Otter!
BE12:02pm

Eleventh is http://deadline.com/tag/pvod/

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Some kind of on-demand screening thing? None of those Deadline articles seems to give a one-line definition.

BE12:03pm

Gah, and we're accused of going native with jargon.

PeterC Pulmonary veno-occlusive disease (PVOD) is a rare form of pulmonary hypertension caused by progressive blockage of the small veins in the lungs?
erlkin would be nice to have some thoughts on gold...but i'm late
Oshi Yamamoto Losing value a little
BE12:04pm

Ah - Premium Video on Demand. The P is premium.

Blank canvas premium video on demand
12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Given the potential threat of PVOD, and the power of the studio as they look to
mitigate declining US cinema attendance, we believe that being one of the largest
global operators means being a partner with the studio's, which we see as critically
important going forward. In the US market particularly there is ongoing debate as
to whether a Premium Video on Demand (or P-VOD) service will be introduced,
whereby consumers can see films at home for c.$30 per film, which they would
otherwise have to wait to watch for three to six months. With the latest news flow
around the situation suggesting an agreement is still not there, we believe that a
solution short-term looks challenging.

BE12:04pm

That's UBS.

BE12:04pm

$30 per film!?

Oshi Yamamoto thats expensive for a film to watch
12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Or, to put it a different way, $30 on a nicked credit card so you can torrent the movie in 4K.

Oshi Yamamoto Downloading bryce
BE12:06pm

That looks another great idea from the industry that gave you DRM and unskippable trailers on DVDs nagging you about buying DVDs.

undefined
12:06 pm
BE12:07pm

Okay, are we done? We're done. I think we're done.

BornCynic Thanks BE for another solo effort - are you ever going to get PM back? I miss the double act.
Oshi Yamamoto Good night and thank you bryce
Soundbuy Cheers..............
BE12:07pm

Thanks for being there, ROTR. Ta for the comments.

rwl thanks all
BE12:07pm

(@BornCynic: shrug emoji.)

Grouchmonkey Don't know why they don't just put box sets on at the cinema. Imagine the popcorn sales from people staggering out bleary eyed for an interval after 4 hours of Breaking Bad?
